body: Replacing VLAs either by malloc/calloc or by static stack allocation. See https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/issues/959 --- This change isâ€‚[](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/1263)

comment_data.body:
Either `uint8_t *const buffer = (uint8_t *)calloc(size ..., sizeof(uint8_t));` or `uint8_t *const buffer = (uint8_t *)malloc(size + 2 * extra);` without the sizeof. If you use sizeof, use calloc.

Same in other places.
Please be consistent. Choose one, and do that everywhere (probably calloc?).
I use calloc where VLA was followed by zeroing memory via `memset`. In other cases malloc (for performance reasons).
Not relevant any more. This place was fixed by zoff99.

comment_regular_data.body: Hm, on my local run all test are passed except `lan_discovery`, which hangs even on clean master...
Can you fix the build failures in this PR?

> Can you fix the build failures in this PR?

I have a feeling that CI fails totally randomly. I'll do my best to fix builds, but there are no guarantees.
https://travis-ci.org/TokTok/c-toxcore/jobs/455236334#L694 needs to be fixed, that's not random.
@crypto-universe can you let me know when you think you've fixed the CI errors to the point where it's no longer fixable in this PR, i.e. it becomes random flakiness?

@iphydf 
I thought that if size of array is known at compile time, it won't be VLA. Sometimes I really lack constexpr and other features from modern C++ :(
I see two options, both are bad:
1. Mallocs everywhere. Slow solution, leads to heap memory fragmentation.
2. Static arrays, global for translation unit (across C file). Fast, but violates good practices and not thread safe.
`enum` in my opinion will be less readable.
Due to `calloc`... I think both methods are well-known and readable. `calloc` is crucial when allocating memory for structures, because it will zero padding bytes inside structure and no info will leak via those chunks of memory.
Normally I build (on Linux) and test my commits before pushing. So it is veeery strange, that CI fails.

In old C++98 that would also be a constant expression. It's just C that doesn't do this (sadly). Don't do static arrays. A third option is to implement the bump-allocator I made an API for the other day. Basically, malloc and free would just bump a pointer in a large pre-allocated array. We'd use a linked list of large memory blocks to allocate from. It would be a stack-like memory allocator next to the runtime stack. I intend to use that anyway at some point (region/arena-based allocation). It avoids malloc for lexically bound allocations. In this PR, I would either use malloc/calloc or make an API for bump allocator and use it, but implement it with plain malloc, deferring the allocator implementation to a separate PR.
That's almost exactly the same as `static int funcB_ints[1024]; int funcB() { ... }` so doesn't solve any of the problems global variables have.
It limits visibility scope to the method where it is defined. This array will be super private.

To be precise, it's almost exactly the same as `static int ints.1796[1024]`, declaring a global symbol with the name `ints.1796` (or some other number). It has the same thread-safety issues as namespace-scope globals. It is a global variable, even if its scope is limited.

On thread safety totally agree.
On the other hand, custom "allocator from a huge preallocated chunk of memory" will have same problem.
Solve it with mutexes... Looks like an overkill. I'd prefer `malloc` way to custom allocator with mutex.

By the way, what is a current status of toxcore: does it use multithreading? As for me, possible multithreading issues should be addressed when they appear...

@crypto-universe toxcore has some thread safety guarantees that are described in the documentation (tox.h). In particular, we guarantee that two instances of toxcore can run in parallel in different threads. Accesses to a single tox instance must be sequential.
Hi, @iphydf ! PR is one year old. I think it is easier to close it and create a new one, from scratch on fresh codebase. What do you think?

Yes, I agree :). Maybe we should talk about how to best handle packet allocations in general. The advantage of VLA/alloca is that

1) only the necessary amount of memory is allocated (as opposed to allocating the maximum packet size)
2) the memory is local to the other parts of the local program memory (cache locality)
3) allocating and deallocating it is *very* fast (compared to malloc/free).

We could achieve most of those goals in a different way, but using malloc/free directly isn't that way. We should check whether it's worth doing something extra to keep these properties, or if malloc/free is actually sufficient for our use case (it probably is).
